description: From French ballade, from Old Occitan ballada (“poem for a dance”), from Late Latin ballare. Doublet of ballade.

entries.meaning: A kind of narrative poem, adapted for recitation or singing; especially, a sentimental or romantic poem in short stanzas.
examples: The poet composed a ballad praising the heroic exploits of the fallen commander.
On Friday nights, the roller rink had a time-block called "Lovers' Lap" when they played nothing but ballads on the overhead speakers.

verbs.description: ballad (third-person singular simple present ballads, present participle ballading, simple past and past participle balladed)

entries.meaning: (obsolete) To make mention of in ballads.
